thread.title: North tops Santa Fe; Nordyke chalks up win No. 500
thread.title_full: North tops Santa Fe; Nordyke chalks up win No. 500

author: THE EDMOND SUN
title: North tops Santa Fe; Nordyke chalks up win No. 500
text:
PHOTO PROVIDED North's Nordyke hits milestone 
Edmond North softball coach Rick Nordyke is surrounded by his troops after notching career-win No. 500 Tuesday night at Edmond North High School. When Nordyke coached baseball, he amassed 463 victories. DREW HARMON   Thomas drives in 2 teammates 
Edmond North Lady Husky shortstop Kennedy Thomas throws to second to get a force out against Edmond Santa Fe Tuesday at Edmond North High School. Thomas knocked in a pair of runs on offense finishing 2-for-4. DREW HARMON   North forces out Santa Fe 
Edmond North second baseman Kendall Cook forces out Edmond Santa Fe's Kori Lacy on Tuesday evening. The Huskies won, 6-3. DREW HARMON   Jones swats hit 
Edmond North's Natalie Jones singles against Edmond Santa Fe Tuesday night. The Huskies went 4-0 to win the city title with three victories over Edmond Memorial. Posted: Thursday, October 1, 2015 7:21 pm 
Edmond North enjoyed a big Tuesday night. 
Rick Nordyke, too. 
The Huskies softball coach registered career-win No. 500, with North taking down crosstown rival Edmond Santa Fe, 6-3 at Edmond North High School. 
The win pushed Nordyke to the milestone and made the Huskies the 2015 city champs, since Edmond North went 4-0 in Edlam clashes, including three wins over Memorial. 
In Tuesday’s game, senior first baseman Julia Minter shined in her final home game, going 3-for-4 with a double and three runs batted in. Shortstop Kennedy Thomas went 2-for-4 and drove in two for the Huskies, while third baseman Amy Crabaugh added two hits and an RBI. 
North scored twice in the first and added two more runs in the fourth to push its lead to 4-1 before the Wolves made it interesting with two unearned runs in the sixth. 
But the Huskies extended the lead again in their half of the sixth, with Minter and Thomas each driving in runs. 
Jillian Helsley started in the circle and went 5 2/3 innings, allowing four hits and one earned run while striking out three. Thomas finished with 1 1/3 innings of scoreless relief for the save. 
Afterward, Nordyke, who won 463 games as Huskies baseball coach, was presented with a plaque and many tributes from former players and coaches were read. The night also featured a celebration of Edmond North’s two state championship teams from 2004 and 2012. Many players and coaches from both squads were on hand and the 2015 girls wore the 2004 uniforms, which included shorts. 
The Huskies close the regular season with two games this weekend at the OC shootout — Friday against Norman North and Saturday against Stillwater — then a trip to Deer Creek on Monday.
